question: Diego is a bright boy -- a pleasure to teach -- but so serious... Brothers should be raised together, Colon. Even brothers from different mothers...
answer: Father, I am doing what I think is the best for him. And he has the teacher I would have chosen for myself.

question: Just be careful you don't lose him. I have something for you. You will be heard at the University of Salamanca...
answer: God... That's in a week!

question: That's what it says.
answer: How did you manage it?

question: With some difficulty. I had to promise them you were not a total fool. Why do you wish to sail west?
answer: To open a new route to Asia. At the moment there are only two ways of reaching it... By sea, sailing around the African Continent -- the journey takes a year... Or by land... ... But the Turks have closed this route to all Christians. Trading with the Orient has become arduous, if not dangerous. There is a third way... By sailing West across the Ocean Sea.

question: How can you be so certain? The Ocean is said to be infinite.
answer: Ignorance! I believe the Indies are no more than 750 leagues west of the Canary Islands.

question: How can you be so certain?
answer: The calculations of Toscanelli Marin de Tyr, Esdras...

question: Esdras is a Jew.
answer: So was Christ!

question: Two minutes... and already you're a dead man. Don't let passion overwhelm you, Colon.
answer: I'll try to remember that, Marchena...

question: Father Marchena!
answer: Passion is something one cannot control!

question: You get so carried away when you are being contradicted!
answer: I've been contradicted all my life... Eternity!

question: Only God knows the meaning of such words, my son.
answer: Diego. Would you like to come and stay with us? I'll do whatever makes you happy.

question: Fernando! Fernando! Executions. In the square. They've agreed to see me in a week. I could be gone for years.
answer: I know.

question: I haven't given you much of a life.
answer: Well... that's true. I have a child by a man who won't marry me! Who's always leaving...

question: Are we going to argue?
answer: I'd love to argue with you sometimes. But you're never here!

question: Perhaps I was never meant to live with a woman...
answer: I find that hard to believe.

question: Fernando, don't you think we are lucky to live with such a beautiful woman?
answer: You say Asia can be found by sailing west?

question: Yes, your Eminence. The voyage should not take more than six or seven weeks.
answer: Unfortunately, Don Colon, that is precisely where our opinions differ... Are you familiar with the work of Aristotle? Erathostene? Ptolemeus?

question: I am, Your Eminence
answer: Then you cannot ignore that according to their calculations, the circumference of the Earth is approximately... 22,000 leagues or more. Which makes the ocean... uncrossable. But you may have found new evidence proving that these men of knowledge are totally mistaken!

question: Your Excellencies are aware of the statements of Marin de Tyr? Then you are also aware that his theories contradict Ptolemeus... De Tyr believes the Ocean to be only 750 leagues... The Florentine Toscanelli and the French Cardinal Pierre d'Ailly both think that Marin de Tyr is accurate in his calculations. And therefore, that the ocean can be crossed. Seven weeks. Six, during the summer months.
answer: Marin de Tyr is wrong -- and has been corrected many times over the centuries by the finest geographers. Your voyage, Don Colon, would take a year!

question: We wouldn't have to turn back! We would find land at this point!
answer: Senor Colon, an experienced captain such as yourself will understand our concern with the crew. I am not willing to have on my conscience the loss of men who would have relied upon our judgment.

question: Excellency, you are right. I am a seaman, not a scholar... But as a simple man craving for knowledge, I have read all the work of these renowned geographers and discovered that none of them could agree on the exact width of this ocean... Therefore, as a modest man, I wonder Who is right? This question remains unanswered. Your Eminence, there is only one way to settle the matter. And that is to make the journey. I am ready to risk my life to prove it possible.
answer: Your life, and that of others!

question: Trade, Your Excellency. According to Marco Polo, the Kingdom of China is one of the richest of the world. Even the meanest buildings are roofed with gold.
answer: Is that all that interests you? Gold?

question: No. The Portuguese have already discovered black-skinned people. I, too, will find other populations -- and bring them to the word of God.
answer: Christopher -- Christo Ferens -- the Bearer of the Cross! If God intended our proximity to Asia, do you believe he would have waited for you to show it to the world?

question: Did He not choose a carpenter's son to reveal Himself to the world?
answer: So you consider yourself the chosen one? Don't you realize your words could be considered heretical?

question: Blind faith is what I consider heresy! Asia can be found to the west -- and I will prove it.
answer: IF-GOD-WILLS-IT! The Treasurer of Spain honors us with his presence.

question: IF-GOD-WILLS-IT! The Treasurer of Spain honors us with his presence.
answer: The State has some reason to be interested in this man's proposition, Your Eminence...

question: The Judgment is ours!
answer: Naturally. But I would really deplore the loss of such a potential opportunity for Spain for a... dispute over a point of geography.

question: He is a mercenary! Did he not already try to convince the King of Portugal of his absurd notions?
answer: Indeed. The world is full of mercenaries -- and states often make use of them, when it benefits them. My only concern is the welfare and prosperity of Spain.

question: You would use your influence to assist this... intriguer?
answer: You know, Your Eminence, the fascinating thing about power, is that what can be given so effortlessly... ... can so easily be taken away.

question: ... and therefore nothing could justify the participation of Your Highnesses in the venture that relies upon such feeble assumptions, and which any man of knowledge would take to be impractical... if not impossible.
answer: They didn't listen. They didn't want to listen!

question: You mustn't give way to despair. You must wait.
answer: Wait! I've waited seven years already! How much longer do you want me to wait?

question: If God intends you to go, then you will go.
answer: Damn God!

question: Colon!
answer: Damn all of you! You all set up theories based on what? You never leave the safety of your studies! Go out! Find out what the world is about and then tell me something I can listen to! These don't mean anything! They're full of assumptions! Out of the heads of old men who've never been past the end of their gardens!

question: No...! My books...!
answer: All of them! Just lies!

question: Rise...! Come forward! I should not even be listening to you, since my council said no. But Santangel tells me you are a man of honor and sincerity... And Sanchez, that you are not a fool.
answer: No more than the woman who said she would take Granada from the Moors.

question: The ocean is uncrossable?
answer: What did they say about Granada before today?

question: That she was impregnable. I cannot ignore the verdict of my council.
answer: Surely you can do anything you want.

question: How little you know.
answer: May I speak freely?

question: You show no inclination to speak otherwise!
answer: I know what I see. I see someone who doesn't accept the world as it is. Who's not afraid. I see a women who thinks... "What if?"...

question: A woman?
answer: Forgive me... but you're the only Queen I know.

question: Then we are equal... since you are the only sailor I know! How old are you, Senor Colon?
answer: Thirty seven, Your Majesty... And you?

question: Thirty eight... You will be informed of our decision.
answer: Actually, I thought you were younger than me!

question: Actually, I thought you were younger than me!
answer: Go on! Furthermore he will receive one eight of all wealth or monies, precious gems, pearls, metals, spices and other lucrative sources conquered within the boundaries of his admiralty... It's very underdone. No, the pheasant. It's almost raw. You worry too much, Carvajal... The man will have to lower his demands. Believe me, he WILL!

question: I WON'T!
answer: We have considered your -- demands very carefully, Senor Colon... Your expectations are... excessive, in every way.

question: If I am right, my requests are fair!
answer: We have prepared our own contract...

question: No...
answer: No?

question: NO...! I have waited too long, fought too hard. Now you expect me to take all the risks while you take the profit! No... I will not be your servant!
answer: I remind you, Senor Colon, that you are in no position to bargain with me.

question: I'm not bargaining!
answer: Then you are too ambitious.

question: And were you never ambitious, Excellency? Or is ambition only a virtue among the nobles, a fault for the rest of us?
answer: If you won't accept our proposal, we'll simply find someone who will.

question: YEEEEEEES! She said yes.
answer: Thank God...

question: If I ever come back, I swear I will...
answer: I'm not asking you to swear to anything.

question: I don't want you to wait for me.
answer: That's something you can't decide.

question: You can't go there!
answer: Why not? There aren't any monsters, Fernando. The only monsters are in here... Watch!

question: I want to go with you!
answer: There'll be a time.

question: You promise? Do you swear on St. Christopher...? Do you swear on all the Holy Saints in heaven?
answer: Yes... Yes, I do... On all of them!

question: Yes... Yes, I do... On all of them!
answer: In Nomine Patris et Filius, et Spiritus Sancti.

question: Forgive me, Father. For I have sinned.
answer: I am listening, my son.

question: Father, I have betrayed my family. I betrayed my men. And I betrayed you.
answer: What are you saying?

question: I lied. The journey will be longer than I said.
answer: How long?

question: I am not sure... It could be twice the distance.
answer: May God forgive you...! You must tell them! You must tell your men!

question: If I tell them, they won't follow me. You know that I am right, Father. You trust me...
answer: My son, my son... Your certitudes are sometimes frightening... Christopher, you must speak to them. And if you don't I will.

question: You are bound by an oath, Father.
answer: I believed in you...

question: Give me absolution. Give me absolution, Father!
answer: Ispo Te Absoluto. May God forgive you and have mercy on your soul, Christopher Columbus. Go in peace.

question: Due west, Captain Mendez. And may God be with us...
answer: God be with us admiral.

question: What is it Mendez? Speak!
answer: Well... It's the men, Sir. They wonder how you know our position. We've lost sight from land days ago...

question: And what do you think Mendez?
answer: Well, I surely know what a quadrant is! But I've never seen it used at night before.

question: Come over here. Now, find the North Star. Do you have it? Steady yourself...! Keep the plumb line vertical... Don't move! A mistake of one degree and we'll be off 6,000 leagues! What do you read?
answer: Twenty eight.

question: Chicken-ass face! Shit! I never seen heat like this! Not even in Las Minas!
answer: The water's going putrid in the barrels.

question: You'll be drinking your own piss... For the glory of Spain... and Admiral Colon...! Bastard! What are you listening to, chicken ass?
answer: Ah, leave him alone. He's doing no harm.

question: With a face like that? I don't want you looking at me. You hear? He's the devil's child...
answer: We'll all go crazy... Culo de galina es el hijo del demonio...

question: Granted.
answer: You lied! You cheated! We're way past 750 leagues!

question: Six days ago, yes.
answer: You must be mad...!

question: We have to keep the hopes of these men alive!
answer: We're on the verge of a mutiny, Colon!

question: You think I don't know that?
answer: We're lost!

question: The land is there. I know it!
answer: You don't know anything! Listen Colon, these are my ships, right? So I'm telling you we're turning back!

question: And then what? Half of the water has gone, the rest is nearly putrid! You know that!
answer: Jesus Maria! I should have never listened to you!

question: You never did. You did all the talking for both of us, remember?
answer: You bloody...

question: Pinzon, Pinzon... All we can do now is go forward! Think about that!
answer: You tell that to them!

question: Who gave you the order to come on board?
answer: God doesn't want us to cross the ocean...! This voyage is cursed!

question: Cursed?
answer: We set sail for greed. God has abandoned us. The voyage is cursed. There are signs...

question: Colon!
answer: We have come here in peace, and we will behave with honor. They are not savages and neither will you be. Treat these people as you would your own wives and your own children. Neither are you free to take what you will; for a seashell you give a bandana. You will respect their beliefs. Pillage will be punished by the whip. Rape by the sword.

question: Gold...! Gold!
answer: Give it to him!

question: By God! That's the worst trade of my life!
answer: October 21st, 1492. I think we have returned to Eden. Surely this is how the world once was, before the beginning of time. I believe no man will ever see this land again as we do, for the first time...

question: He cures. You come! You speak first!
answer: Tell the Chief we thank him.

question: Chief knows.
answer: Tell him his country is very beautiful. Tell him we are leaving men here -- to build a fort. Tell him we will return very soon. Many of us.

question: Chief says -- how many?
answer: Thousands.

question: Why?
answer: To bring the word of God.

question: Chief says -- he has a God.
answer: ... and also to bring medicine.

question: Chief says...
answer: He has medicine. Tell him we admire his people.

question: Chief says he knows you like his... Women...
answer: That's a beginning... March 1493... Thirty nine of my men volunteered to stay behind. God willing we will be back in less than a year... ... Several men are ill. We did not find signs of civilization. No cities, no temples... Nothing that resembles Marco Polo's descriptions. My ships are not filled with the spices and the gold that Spain was hoping for. But this land intoxicates the senses like the strongest of perfumes... And all I can think of, is to return to these untamed lands... Get below! All of you! Go! Stay with me! We may have to cut it! I'll stay here -- to decide if we cut it. Help me! Now go! I said -- below deck, Mendez! One... two... three... four... Damn you! One... two... three... four... five...

question: I understand that you will soon be appointing Governors for the islands? Is it not so?
answer: Forgive me, Don Bobadilla -- those positions have already been taken.

question: May I ask by whom?
answer: Bartolome and Giacomo Colon.

question: I trust they are men of quality.
answer: But we do have a lack of notaries. You should contact my administration.

question: Is this your new world, Don Colon?
answer: No Guevara. There will be no revenge.

question: We lost cousins, friends. We will wash this in blood.
answer: If you want to keep your head on your shoulders, you'll do as I say. Moxica, I lost friends too... Thirty nine brave men who trusted me. You want a war? Fine. We are a thousand. They outnumber us by ten! Who will you kill? Which tribe?

question: We don't need to know.
answer: We came here to stay! To build! Not to start a crusade. In this forest, there is enough danger to sweep us away in days! So we will be brave and swallow our grief. And in the name of those who died, we will accomplish what we came for.

question: Ask him if he will help. Don Moxica -- we need your horse. We can't raise the wheel without it.
answer: My horse doesn't work.

question: Don Moxica -- we all have to work.
answer: You did not hear me, Don Colon. Not my horse.

question: Forgive me, Don Moxica. But it was your horse I was talking about. Thank you, Don Moxica.
answer: To the Governor of the Mosquitoes! Do you want her?

question: What is it?
answer: Eat! I'll tell you later.

question: I'd like to know what I'm eating.
answer: Iguana. What wrong with it? The Indians eat it!

question: We've got to learn to live like the Indians. Eat your Iguana! How much gold have we found?
answer: Not enough to justify a single shipment.

question: Perhaps it doesn't exist anywhere but in my imagination.
answer: Then let's hope not... What will happen if we can't find enough gold?

question: He's lying! Bring him here! Tell him to put his hands on the table. Like this! Tell them I want them to watch this! I can't? I can't?
answer: In one act of brutality, you have created chaos. Tribes who were fighting each other are now joining forces against us! All that because of your criminal savagery!

question: Savagery is what monkeys understand.
answer: You'll be held in detention, deprived of your privileges and possessions. Until you are returned to Spain where you will be judged. Have you anything to say?

question: I wish to go back with them, Don Colon. I have no desire to remain in this godless place.
answer: You may do as you please, Brother Buyl -- though your departure will not help me to make it more Godly.

question: You treat Christians equally with heathen savages. You execute members of the nobility. And what do you offer in return?
answer: A new world, Brother Buyl.

question: Nobody wants one...! Only you!
answer: Perhaps hope only exists in the journey. When it begins, everything is still possible -- every expectation; every dream... This is not how I imagined it to be. Utapan! Utapan, won't you speak to me? You used to know how to speak to me.

question: Don Alonso de Bobadilla.
answer: Yes... I remember...

question: My letters of appointment.
answer: Appointment to what?

question: Viceroy of the West Indies.
answer: Congratulations. Then I am free to search for the mainland.

question: Didn't you learn? The mainland was discovered. Weeks ago. By another Italian. I forgot his name.
answer: How far from here?

question: I am not a seaman. But I heard it is no more than a week at sea. I hope you are not too disappointed.
answer: How could I be? The mainland has been found. Exactly as I said it would.

question: Fernando...! My God...! A man! Diego, how did this happen?
answer: Santangel is going to see the Queen. We are going to get you out of here.

question: Good! I have to go back!
answer: Go back?

question: This time with me!
answer: In your present state it is madness, Father!

question: Nobody is forcing you to come with us.
answer: I can't go anyway.

question: Is he? Really? Rise... Please...
answer: Now I do look older than you.

question: We have decided to allow you to undertake another voyage to the new world... But without your brothers. Nor are you to return to Santo Domingo or any of the other colonies. You may explore the continent.
answer: Thank you.

question: There is one thing I'd like to understand... Why do you want to go back, after all this?
answer: Your Majesty -- some men are content to read about things. I must see them with my own eyes. I cannot be other than I am.

question: All I have to do is call the guards.
answer: Call them.

question: I am not afraid of you. You are nothing but a dreamer.
answer: Look out of that window. What do you see?

question: Roofs... towers, palaces... spires...
answer: All of them created by people like me. No matter how long you live, Sanchez, there's something that will never change between us. I did it! You didn't! God... you're so beautiful! I can't believe no other man has ever taken you away from me...

question: Not everything... Do you think I care? I'm a free man again. Riches don't make a man rich, they only make him busier... God, how much I've missed you!
answer: One chair. One table. What more can a man expect, when he tries to sue the Crown?

question: I owe you everything, Santangel... but as you see, I can't repay you.
answer: On the contrary. It is I who owe you everything. Through you, I have been an adventurer, an explorer! It's true I shall never see the new world... but it's here... And here... What you are, Colon, is a sailor, a discoverer, a man of imagination... not a politician. You weren't meant to govern -- You cannot be all things to all men. I wish you could have compromised. It would have made your life easier...

question: The mainland...
answer: What's he doing?

question: He's drawing an isthmus... He's saying we're on an isthmus.
answer: We can't be.

question: Tell me what he's saying. Ask him if he means a lake. A big lake. An ocean...? He's says it's an ocean?
answer: I don't understand.

question: Here is Europe... and over here, the continent of Asia. But there's something in between! Another continent! We've found... another continent!
answer: Father...

question: There must be a passage to that other ocean.
answer: Oh my God...

question: I suppose we're both old men now.
answer: You'll always be older than me, Father. Have you ever forgiven me?

question: Yes. I forgave you a long time ago. You see, I was proud of you. You were like a willful child. You wouldn't accept what others told you. You had to find things out for yourself, hurting yourself -- and others -- in the process. Do you remember when you said that people talk about the world, but never leave their gardens. More than ever I wonder what it is we do achieve by leaving our gardens... The world changes -- and yet it seems the same. We find new worlds, but fill them with the same people...
answer: I have to disagree.

question: I knew you would.
answer: New worlds create new people.

question: Oh? So you are a new man?
answer: I don't know... I have the impression that I didn't change that much. I still can't accept the world as it is!

question: God bless you, and those like you!
answer: Can't you stay with us a little?
